title: Adoxophyes orana
text:
Adoxophyes orana, the summer fruit tortrix, is a <a href="moth">moth</a> of the family <a href="Tortricidae">Tortricidae</a>. It is found in the <a href="Palearctic%20realm">Palearctic realm</a> and <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.
The <a href="wingspan">wingspan</a> is 17–22 mm. The moth flies in two generations from May to November. The larvae overwinter in loosely woven cocoons.
The larvae feed on various trees and shrubs with a preference for <a href="Rosaceae">Rosaceous</a> plants, particularly <a href="apple">apple</a> ("Malus domestica") and <a href="pear">pear</a> ("Prunus pyrifolia"). The species is considered a pest due to the damage the larvae do to fruit trees while feeding.
